reviews.review_msg: His slides lack the information needed to properly explain the material and he does not do a great job of explaining things clearly either. He lectures in a way that assumes you already know the material. A lot of people got less than 40% on the final.
Great lectures.

Great presenter, very basic lecture notes lacking whats needed to know on exams, definitely use a lot of external resources (videos, practice questions), cocky annoying know it all who thinks everything is easy - of course it's easy for the prof, very very difficult exams, midterm was okay, final was death, one of the worst profs I've ever had

He has very clear notes. He doesn't focus on mechanisms but more on "here is the final product, what were the reactans". His lectures went by fast. I recommend using his notes as a starting point and find youtube videos that explain the topic in more detail. The class averages were 50-60%. Obviously the best prof at teaching o-chem.
His lectures are very clear and concise, shows a lot of real-world examples for reactions... He doesn't provide too much detail for each reaction so it's best to review them in a textbook after

It took less than a lecture for myself and many other students to realize we were in the presence of a true genius - something rare even among professors. Unparalleled mastery of the material. Very to the point. Emphasized understanding and tested on it. Provided context and humor to engage. Not at all arrogant. Just wish he had office hours.

Great professor. He always started class by showing us real world applications to what we would be learning that day. Classes always went by in a flash. Tests were difficult as you had to say the one specific key word to get any marks at all. Chem 282 is easy for some, and hard for others. Branda, keeps it fun for everyone.

Knows what he's talking about. The exams require original thought and problem solving. So if you just went through the lecture notes you'll get stuck on the exam unless you understand a certain amount of theory... and obviously you need to memorize certain reactions. Do lots of problems and you should be OK.
Best chem prof ever. He's so enthusiastic and passionate; it makes lectures fun and interesting. Great teaching style-he explains concepts really well. Funny guy!
Hard material,  but notes were provided and there was no need to use the textbook.
He's the man.

Seriously great prof. This is a tough class. If you don't put in the time, you won't get the mark. I got 63% on my midterm for silly mistakes, class average was 62%. The midterm was straight forward, no tricks. He makes you understand the reasoning behind the importance of chemistry and its impacts in our everyday life. 100% recommended prof.
man..i miss this guy so much although i'm takin 282 with other prof..
Simply the best

so far the best prof at sfu i've ever had. he shows the class real-world examples that are actually interesting. his notes are awesome. and he gives bonus questions that are challenging. would highly recommend. i wish he taught all my chem courses.
interesting lectures without getting off topic
Very hard on the final exam !!!!!!!!

If you read the comments below, you will see that the trend is that Dr. Peggy is a great prof, the course is very heavy and requires a lot of studying every week. She delivers it like it is. No surprises. You study and know the problem sets well and you will get a good mark. Shes very approachable and is available when needed.
Peggy is a great prof, funny too. The problem is the course is quite challenging. Do the tutorial problems, read the textbook, and keep up in class or you'll fall behind.
Hard ass final. Gotta know your stuff. Teaches the material as if it were easy to comprehend, but that's because she's a researcher, not a professor first.

This course is no walk in the park and you need to keep up or fear falling behind. However, Peggy is an awesome prof and I would definitely recommend her! The midterm was easy but the final is challenging. Practice practice PRACTICE! Read the textbook and notes! Overall, she is an excellent prof! I'm not sure why some students don't like her...

There is no prof equal to even half of what Dr P is. She is the only prof so far who made chem fun! The midterm was a joke, but the final was quite difficult if you don't challenge yourself when you study. Read the lectures, do questions in the textbook, do tutorial questions. Practice makes perfect. Overall, excellent prof, excellent course.

I think she is a nice prof. Her notes are very organized almost like textbook!!! However, the course is a ball breaker but she helps the students to understand the material well and if you keep up you should get away with a C+.

As helpful as she can be, it's always a challenge to go and see her, I know I went to see her once because I had trouble with a few reactions and she made me feel stupid, and kept saying if you read the notes it's all there, well I obviously read the notes and that's why I came to see you, because I didn't understand, good prof though
Really good. I think people do bad cause it's a hard class and blame the prof. She's always got office hours and very fair exams wit fair marking.

The final was actually very hard, but if you study, you will do well, I can see why majority of people were freaked out by the final afterward, but study hard and you will pass hopefully. Chem 282 is not an easy course, and the final was definitely harder than the midterm. If you don't understand the concepts, you will mess up on the final
she is really nice and a very good lecturer. she's always willing to help and her final was really easy! if you study the notes and problem sets you will do well in this class! :)

She is a very good lecturer and explains concepts very well. She is always available for extra help but she expects you to study hard. Her exams are a bit on the hard side but overall she is a very nice woman.
I personally like the professor, the midterm is fair. Lectures are recommended since she goes over her slides in details.
unlike 281, practice problems were no help

Robert is an amazing prof. Explains things well in lecture, but notes are hand-written and not posted online. The material is difficult, and yes, you will have to pay attention in class to understand what's going on. For what the course is, I wouldn't want to take it with anyone else except him. Very approachable, fair exams, but study hard.

This course was ridiculously hard, but even when you think you're going to fail, keep going. I thought I was going to fail for sure, but I kept working hard until the very end and I passed! I didn't do well on the midterm and the final, but tutorial participation and assignments really help your mark. Be prepared for hard exams, but don't give up!

Very nice professor. Explains things pretty well. The course itself was hard - there was a lot to memorize. His assignments were a bit difficult, but pay attention to the chemistry of the reactions! The midterms and final were fair, but not easy.   Dr Britton seems to be very knowledgeable.
midterm was fair (he scaled it because no one got perfect). Mostly concept questions from his notes. The final was hard and he did not scale the final.

Dr. Britton is a great prof but the course itself is very difficult. He does handwritten notes, but you really need to understand the concepts yourself, which I learned the hard way. The assignments and tutorial questions were okay but the midterm and final were quite difficult and unlike the practice tests.

Midterm was fair ( from his notes). Final was hard... He scaled the midterm because no one got perfect. The course is tough .. I spent way too much time on it and just passed .. Read ahead and come to class .. You'll be fine .

I put all my time and energy in this course, but I still found it extremely difficult. I find people rate him high just because he's funny/good looking. That doesn't help in terms of his exams, and his notes didn't either because they were scattered and his exam questions were so abstract. If you're not a chem major, you'll probably have trouble.
Fantastic prof, tests were fair and you would do well if you studied. I wish I had taken 283

Great Guy!!! Need to keep on top of the material but exams were fair and lecture notes were awesome! Feel like the other comments were unfair, it is a tough course, but if you put in the work it's not bad.
TESTS were WAY too hard

Rob is an excellent professor, one of the best at SFU. Very clear in his teaching and genuinely interested. Always writes his own notes on the overhead so you're forced to keep up, which is wonderful. He's easy to talk to is more than happy to answer questions. Mid term was good but as expected, the final was tough. Take his class!

Wasn't even close to passing his midterm. I studied hard for it, but for some reason he decides to put tricky questions and molecules that we haven't even seen before on the exam, COMPLETELY UNFAIR. I studied hard, and my efforts were a waste because the exam questions are way harder than anything we seen in class or his practice midterms.

Just got the results of the midterm back and failed it by A LOT, and I didn't even do that bad in 281. His midterm was long compared to his practice ones, and had a lot of tricky questions that weren't in the examples provided in his notes. If you are not naturally gifted in chem, DON'T TAKE HIS CLASS. Goes way too fast when teaching.

He's probably one of my favourite chem prof's ever. Really helpful, his notes are all you'll need to do well in his course so attend lectures! Not too much homework, but tutorials are mandatory. The midterms were fair, keep note on things he mentions in class but final was HARD! Awesome teacher regardless

Super nice guy, obviously loves what he teaches. Explained things pretty well, and was always willing to answer questions or explain in more depth when needed. His first midterm was relatively fair, but the final was super difficult, much harder than anything we had ever encountered in class or homework. Also, class isn't scaled/bell curved at all.
He is the man!!

Amazing prof! Kept me awake during the lectures and managed to make the material learnable. I thought the midterm was very fair, BUT his final killed me (and i'm pretty sure most of the class, from the looks on people's faces):s

Personally, he is a really good prof than others. the midterm was fair, BUT the final was really hard. The practice final exam was not helpful than I expected. The updated final exam is way harder than previous final exam (practice final exam)

Great teacher, great notes, and great attitude. Go to tutorials because they are there to help reinforce the greatness too. His notes and problem sets help so much. Fair midterm and exam!! wanna take take his CHEM 455 class!!!
Make sure you go to lectures. Also, he recycles his assignments, so if you can get a hold of his old assignments, you get a free 15%.
He is the man. He is very knowledgeable and tells you what you are suppose to know for exam. Highly recommended. I wish I had him for chem 286. Britton, you the best!
An extremely helpful prof, his exams are very fair and he is always willing to help or give advice.

Extremely good prof! His lectures and notes were really useful! Very helpful during office hours; no question is stupid for him. Course overall is really hard; so was his final. A lot of reactions to understand.

The best prof I have ever  taken a class with. Yes the course material is alot of work but I'm not kidding when I say if u show interest in the course material, Britton will make sure u get everything u need to know. He had review sessions for Chem 281 material that he held aside from the office hours which were very helpful so yes, he is the best!

ok so i came to this site before to see if i should register in this dude's class since sophie laveiri was a complete fail.  and it looked like he was a good prof but hes really not. writes down notes and talks way too fast for one to absorb anything hes saying.  and he acts like all this stuff is common knowledge when its so hard!

WOOOW! one of the best prof i've ever had! fair tests, crystal clear notes, and reasonable office hrs, u just couldnt ask for more. two things u need to ace his courses: read his notes and do the practice in text and his tutorials. if most ppl screw on one test, big chance he will rescale the mark (what a nice person...)

What a nice guy. He explains everything, even stuff from 281 so even if u didn't learn anything from it, u wont be lost. The exams were quite tough, but it's stuff that he has covered. His notes were awesome!

Great prof, good, clear and concise notes. exams fair although the memorizing of reactions is a bit tedious. Tip for exams: Make sure to know your proton acidity and molecule acidity (about 1/4 final exam around that). Bonus: provides practice questions before finals. Definitely recommended

GREAT prof. he encourages students to go to his office hours, and if you go, go early! there's always lots of ppl waiting. he explains things very clearly and is always happy to answer questions. his finals are hard because his midterms are pretty easy. go to class and be prepared to write as he does notes on the overhead.

Organic II was hard, his notes were extremely clear, a he answered questions in and out of class. The mid term was a joke compared to the final, but the final was fair. Assignments easy at first way too hard there after. Good prof overall if you find organic chem to be hard take it with this guy.

a lot of information to learn in a very short period of time for the intersession format, but he cares a lot and is very knowledgable. final exam is extremely difficult and does not fully reflect what was learned in lecture and tutorials

Does not care about students. He'll do pop quizzes online on Canvas in class and if you're somebody who writes out their notes, or don't have an electronic device, wifi not working etc, he literally will not care. Would not recommend.

As an intersession course, chem was very fast-paced. Chem 282 requires you to teach yourself most of the material. The exams were very long but doable. Youtube and a good textbook can easily get you a good grade. His lectures told you what reactions u need to know and a couple of examples. The real learning you have to do by yourself. Nice guy tho

The material is really hard, but he did a decent job teaching it. He asked for a lot from us and I kept falling behind, but I still understood some concepts. The exams were unfair, especially compared to past exams, and it was very conceptual based and not straightforward. I do respect him as a Lab Professor and I think he excels more in that area.

Avoid taking classes with Dr. Kreis if you can. It was an online semester, and we were struggling with his exams. He teaches you only the basics, and the exams are extremely hard to finish. You will need loads of question to practice on. The average for the first was 35% which blew my mind. Please try to take this course with another professor.

Hes a nice guy who loves chem but he is not good at teaching. Exam averages always around 30-40% and yet he still doesnt take responsibility for it or change. He barely explains anything and expects us to have the same understanding as him on exams. A really bad experience overall, please dont put yourself through this.

I get we're in the middle of a pandemic but he did a flipped classroom model which was so difficult for us as students, and when asked for feedback he didn't really change much. His midterm was very difficult with a 47% average, he doesn't explain much and expects us to know how to solve complex problems when he has not even taught the bare min.
You know there's something wrong with the prof when nearly 50% of the class fails the first exam. Never take this class with him, it is a nightmare.

Criminally poor at teaching. Does not facilitate the learning of his students, ridicules students for the questions they do ask, and blames students for their inability to understand his poor explanations. Absolutely horrendous prof, the worse I have ever had.

Dr. Kreis has definitely impacted the way that I learn and approach my education. Ca be serious, but also very friendly and engaging. He asks key leading questions to help you make connections yourself. Always cares about student needs. Be ready to participate actively. Don't be scared away by bad reviews, I almost did.

He's a really jolly prof during lecture. He'll always ask questions so you should be prepared with some to take advantage. And his exams are straight forward, you can literally go through the practice exam and pass.

Dr Kreis may seem hard to approach at first, but he's acutally a great prof. He explains concepts very well and encourages questions every class. As long as you don't fall behind on the material and keep up on the material you will do fine. Asking questions will help greatly with understanding the material!

One of the worst profs I have ever had! I would not recommend taking this class with him unless you are extremely gifted at ochem. He has terrible notes, does not engage the class and is very bad at explaining concepts. Avoid taking this class with him if you can.
Avoid taking OChem with Kreis!! Not very helpful and makes you feel stupid when you ask for clarification. Rarely draws out the mechanisms and horrible notes. Class avg for the final was 35%!

DON'T TAKE OCHEM WITH HIM! Unless you're naturally gifted in organic chemistry or have loads of time to try to understand everything he expects you to know, take it with someone else. His notes have no detail, exams are way too hard and he isn't very approachable. The final exam avg was 35% !!!!

Refused to provide a course outline. You're expected to tease out the important topics from his notes and research them on your own. Rarely wrote out rxn mechanisms. Finished the material almost 2 weeks ahead of schedule (in condensed course!). Didn't post tutorial problems or lecture notes in reasonable time frame. Class avg for final was 35%. Wow
His notes are horrible and his lectures are not informative. He does not follow the textbook at all. Don't take the class with him, seriously!

Anyone who is complaining about the class being hard is probably a biology major and can't keep up with a quantitative class. Dr. Kreis will not only teach you organic chemistry but how to learn properly. One of the greatest professors, i could easily say he changed the way i approach school.

Kries is actually a very interesting prof.He is honestly not like how people have described him to be.282 is a hard course and he tries his best to make it easy for the students to understand. His exams are very fair, may be the final was a bit hard but again as long as you keep up with the material you'll be fine. He made me love CHEM. =)

He isn't as bad as everybody says. Gives you marks for attendance of tutorials and a group presentation + group assignment which are just free marks. Exams are hard but it is organic chem so you shouldn't expect it to be easy anyways. He split final into 3 midterms you didn't even have to learn the last 1/3 of the class to get an ok grade.

You have to be a GREAT listener to get anything out of him. He's kinda moody too, and he doesnt like u if u're not smart. our class avg is ard 55%.his lecture is ALL over the place compare to the book (bruice 5th).clearly, u gotta do extra research n his sample tests if u wanna survive. If u're not a chem genius LOOK ALIVE

I do not find his lectures are useful as his teaching really really bad... his notes are useless, do not explain the material in detail...Mts are fair.. overall i do not recommend him,and please avoid him

He has an interesting way of teaching. You gotta be proactive in lectures and ask what you don't know. He won't make you feel stupid if you ask a question, he will just make you think before giving you an answer. Midterms are really fair, just make sure you go to class and understand the material. Good prof!

Kreis teaches well, his notes are very clear and his lectures are very straight forward. Exams are not difficult at all. He is somewhat lazy though, but I think that's because he's already so damn good at his job he does not need much effort to do it well. Overall a recommendable prof to just about anyone.
excellent prof,exams are very fair, unlike merbouh's, recommended

Hey I took this course in the semester summer 2010 and I think Kreis is the best professor I've ever had for organic chemistry. He explains the concepts with startling clarity and reasonable level of helpfulness, but he can be a bit hard to take in all at once which is why it was useful for me to listen to his audio lectures over and over.
Good professor overall

He is the best chemistry proffesor at SFU. I took chem 282 and 286 with him and I got an A and A- without doing lots of work. His class average is high (around 70%) compared to that of the village idiot Merbouh. He is nice, easy, encouraging, approachable, loves teaching instead of just lecturing. I totaly recommend him.

He's an OK prof, he powerpoints lectures, this isn't too bad of a course to do well in. Just memorize!!!!!!!!! he's had a few lectures on goals and integrity, i thought htat was kinda .. useless, lol imo. exams are quite deadly tho
His exams are deadly.
deadly exams but awesome prof
he is a smart guy and i have to admit he does teach well. His notes are simple but you have to take notes from what he says too which is what he will likely to test on.

I had him for 282 and 286 in Summer '04. Kreis Powerpoints everything and it doesn't work well for org-chem. In addition, in lab, if he thinks you're not doing the work, he WILL give you a hard time about it. Unlike Hanlan, he'll treat you like an idiot if you don't know the answer, but he WILL give you the answer straight out eventually.

what the heck u pple talking abt..Kries is the best chem prof and he doesn't make u cry..are u insane?? His notes on merchanisms are pretty good..the textbook i used sucked though (Jones Chemistry) overall he's a good prof..he explains the mechanisms and draws them out for u, just pay attention and work hard for this class =D and u'll be fine :D

Mechanisms, Mechanisms, Mechanisms.  Keep up (or ahead) on text readings, or you will be screwed.  Doesn't care if you havn't learned prerequisite material for what he teaches.  Midterms are hard but you can redeem yourself on the final if you study hard.  Let's see how ze molecule looks like, ya? Lol, what a German.  LERNEN SIE CHEMIE!!

i waited 2 semesters just to avoid this prof , but it seems like he is the only one to teach. As I expected , none of my friends get a clue what he had explained in his lectures because he expects us to know EVERYTHING from previous lecturers and chem 281

By the end of this course you will feel as if you were nailed by the hands and feet to a giant test-tube clamp wearing a crown of broken pipettes, and a fithy lab coat tied round your waist...we call it kreisification.

lots of mechanisms that you need to know and his notes aren't the most detailed on some of them. his midterm and final are super hard, he expects you to know a good chunk of the course and have as good as an understanding as he does. tough course but interesting.

He goes over concepts thoroughly. He's great at explaining things and his answers give you a better understanding of chemistry. If you add good notes to his slides, you'll find the notes a very good studying resource. However, he tends to sort of jump back and forth through the material, so it can be a little hard to follow his train of thought.
His class is HARD. but if you pay attention to what he said in class, and read the notes, you should have no problem. He is a great prof.

he's not tat bad..he just wants us to think..n the course is curved, so even if he puts questions tat no one can answer..it wont really affect our grades...but there is just too much to cover for a 2 credit course...

He doesn't give out reading lists or which textbook to use.  His midterms are tricky.  He put things on them that we never see before.  He makes you memorize the IR values and the chemical shifts.  Even though the course is only 2 credits it is actually like a 4 credit course.
Final was ok but overall it is  very very very HARD!!!!!!
No Comments
No Comments
give the eziest example first ok??????

it's amazing how he spends half of the class to answer ppl's questions cuz his explanation is really unclear. His notes are really disorganized. if u really want to take hard organic course, take with him.

he's been teaching this class so bad branda takes all the blame. but teaching organic has to b based on understanding not memorizing everything. u have to b a real chemist to get thru this course cuz a textbook is the only source u have and reading lists won't b provided.
this class is HORRIBLE!! U really have to learn the course at home with ur text book, his lecture notes are completely useless...its like USELESS! anyways, the average is a 45%..so u decide!
If u like ur exam avg's to b around 7% this is the prof uve been waiting for!!! U must take it with him
It is a HARD class!!!!!!!! toooo much work for a 2 credit course.

he's not tat bad, but a lot of memorizing, n he does put stuff u nvr learn on da exams to test ur skills, n of coz no one gets them tats y da avg is low. i laugh at wat ladybug's friend says how he wants us to die, a prof doesnt want their students to fail! just work hard. but he does waste time on teaching us how to learn..useless
No Comments

Was the last comment be written by Uwe? Horribly difficult class! Many of us lack prior knowledge (thanks Branda) but they need to put their rivalries aside & get their**** together or they'll keep loosing students to other faculties. He seems to enjoy watching us suffer. Exams & tutorials hideously difficult. Makes you hate organic chem. How sad.

He must be given a teaching award. I am learning alot in his class. He is amazing,helpful,and gives excellent lectures.There are too many stupid people in this class, so just ignore the comments below. If you work really hard in this course, you will enjoy organic chemistry.He is the best of best at SFU.

Useless. You come out of lecture knowing less than you did going in. Material gets harder, but teaching doesn't get any better. To the person who said all negative comments are untrue - take a look at your colleagues in class, and see how they feel.
this guy is useless. he expects you to be a chemistry genius and doesn't seem to get why his midterm averages are so bloody low.
No Comments

i really had high expectation for this course since i really enjoyed chem 281 with Dr.Brenda. but he has taught me 3 things so far. 1)chemistry is hard 2)chemistry is all aobut memorization 3)chemistry is not fun :)

Makes exams hard by withholding knowledge as opposed to making things logically difficult. Difficult to approach. Loves powerpoint - but doesn't lecture with it well (very passive teaching style). Has no logical progression of difficulty in tutorial questions - you just get hard stuff immediately.

Worst teacher in the world! Do not take a class with him. Doesn't assign a txt book, explains vague concepts in lecture and then expects you to know small details. Unapproachable and will yell at you if you don't know something that he thinks you should. TA said she would have a tough time taking his test.
No Comments
SIMPLY THE WORST. TAKE THE LECTURE WITH HIM IF YOU WISH TO STUDY A LONG DISTANCE COURSE.
i think he should be teaching lab only. he's really unclear of explaning things. he spent 20 mins of lecture to answer questions while no one knows what he's talking about.
He is the best prof ever.
Kreis is Kreepy. And what is up with the super long fingernails, and his bizarre stare? Organic chem is weird enough...Kreis just adds major creep factor to it.
He is the best prof to talk to and ask questions from.I learned so much in his class because I worked insanely hard and asked him lots of questions. He exams are interesting and challenging.

He expects alot from students. His exams are hard. He uses powerpoint notes. He RARELY goes over the mechanisms. The average of midterm and quizzes were below 50%. He rather spent time on studying strategies than on mechanisms! Worst prof I ever had!

He makes chem282 a nightmare. In fact, he makes organic/chem a nightmare too. We have to memorize lots of "classis" rxn amoung with basic princples of rxn. In the exam, he will give you a starting materials and lots of arrows, everything else is
His chem282 course is very different to others.

One of THE BEST profs i ever had and i had quite a few. If u ask "smart" questions u will do well. He stayed with me at 6 pm and made sure i understood everything. I got home tired but READY for the test. He is FUNNY, SMART, COOL AND KIND.
very clear about her expectations concerning examinatable material, and a fairly generous marker

vance is a nice prof. good notes but doesn't follow the textbook closely which is understandable for an organic chem course. the problem sets closely resemble his exam questions so be sure to do them. it's a hard course so be prepared to work for your grade!

An alright prof, his exams are fair, final might be a bit harder. Be sure to do the problem sets and attend tutorials. His notes are ok, its more clear when you read the book. He has 3 marking schemes, so that you can achieve the highest mark possible, which is good :)
He is the best prof I've ever met in SFU.I waited for almost one year and a half to choose his course.sounds stupid, but the waiting is worth. He makes everything clear, I learn a lot.
He's slow-paced and very clear in writing notes. But this course still requires lots of practice if you want to get high marks on the exam.
Great Prof! notes easy to follow, fair exams

Goes at a slow pace, which would normally make me fall asleep but I find that I never get bored in his class and understand almost everything he says.  Pretty good prof - very organized. 1st midterm was fair, 2nd midterm was a bit tough.
V. slow pace, colourful handwrttn notes, speaks clearly, pauses a lot. Exams are fair. Extremely nice nerdy young guy.
his exams are fair......and his notes are really useful for studying
Very fair.
dull yet his tests are somewhat easier than Neil's

The lectures could be disorganized, but the professor clearly outlined exam content. Make cheat sheets and flashcards for reactions - it really helped me prepare using Unstuck AI alongside the textbook.

Chem 282 is not a class that you could just easily self study and teach everything to yourself. Having a good prof and a good TA really helps which Andrew Bennett and his rude TA's are far away from it. DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE WITH HIM I'm surprised why some people here have rated him more than 2. this course made me hate chemistry.

wasn't the best, but also not the worst because the flow of lectures were not very organized. however, was very clear of what is on the exam. tip: make a sheet cheat and flashcards for all the reactions b4 hand, exams are cumulative!!

I took the first Ochem in another institution and took the second one here with Professor Bennet after I transferred to SFU. So there were many concepts that I hadn't learnt in Ochem 1 which were necessary for his class. So I asked him questions after each lecture. He really helped me a lot. I wish I could learn from him more. Good caring person!

ABJ is a truly mediocre prof. If you understand Chem, you'll be fine, if not, maybe avoid him. I didn't learn anything from his lectures and had to teach most of the material. Exams are very hard but all chem exams are. Curve is pretty strong, 50% average on exams = C+

Dr. Bennet is horrendous. By far the worst prof I have ever had at SFU. As other reviews have said, he makes course content 100x harder than it actually should be. Tests did not feel like assessments of our understanding - they were astronomically difficult. I would seriously not recommend taking his class to anyone. He is awful.

Horrible teacher! Grade is based on solely exams and there is barely any homework to practice what you've learned. His lecture slides have no definitions, just examples as if you already know what he's talking about. No assigned textbook, although I recommend you get one so you can teach yourself the course (it was the only way I scraped a pass)
Worst chemistry prof ever

Horrible professor. Notes were messy and inefficient. Lectures confused me more. Did not care about chem. The class average for the midterm was around 50 and he refused to scale because someone got 100%. Did not learn a single thing from him. DO NOT TAKE A CLASS WITH HIM UNLESS YOU WANT TO LEARN NOTHING AND GET A BAD GRADE.
Horrible prof, idk why he's even allowed to teach chemistry. Marking is 10% iclicker, 35% first exam, 55% 2nd exam.

Old fashioned lecture with infficient note taking using overhead camera.  
He explains like you are chem major. The way he explains makes material more difficult
Going over minimal mechanisms, with minimal note taking
Marks not spread out through assignments
Thanks to youtube and google. They are the only reason i could understand anything.

He makes ochem more difficult than it actually is. I didnt learn anything from his lectures/slides and up until this point Ive been attempting to teach myself everything. Ive never withdrawn from a course before but am seriously considering it.
He really does makes already difficult things more difficult. He should not be teaching.

Just badI have a midterm with him tomorrow and I learned absolutely NOTHING from him. Been teaching myself the whole course. Avoid him at all costs. He doesnt even teach the material properly, only the tas were helpful

Dr. Bennet was a nice professor. Although organic chemistry is a difficult subject, he makes it seem even more difficult with his monotone voice and recorded lectures split into multiple parts, 7 at most. Friendly and understanding during office hours. Tutorials were helpful! Grade is made of only exams, so if you're a bad test taker.. feels bad.
Dont take this class with him, the other profs are FAR better at explaining the material.

Alright, so he was a decent prof, but he couldn't communicate all the material well. His midterm was 100% fair, but the final had like 3 questions from the problem sets and the rest was IMPOSSIBLE. I actually knew what I was doing and was doing practice exams from the prof in surrey and was getting about 70%. HEAVILY HEAVILY SCALED! final avg = 32%
His notes were terrible and his explanations sucked. Probably make it even more confusing tbh. Exams were way harder compared to homework problems. Don't take 282 with this guy if possible.
tough course with terrible instructor+disorganize notes you can easily end up getting bad mark on final exam.
simply the worst instructor ive ever had. It hard to understand anything in the lecture and its extremely hard to follow his notes.

The course is hard and he seemed to make it a hell of a lot harder. His lectures made no sense at all. Midterm average 51%, final average 30 something % :S I'd take it with someone else. Worked my butt off for a terrible grade.
It's hard to learn the material just by attending lectures. His notes are not horrible, but definitely not amazing either. This course is heavily scaled anyways.
terrible notes + terrible explanations

I went to every lecture, and I never understood anything he said until I would read the textbook. I only went to motivate myself to study, because every time I'd go, I would have no idea what he was saying. This would freak me out, so I would try and study quite a bit for this class. The TA I had was halpful though.

Worst prof I've ever had, teaching a difficult class. Lectures and notes were all over the place and extremely hard to follow. If you're not an ochem genius do NOT take 282 with him. I ended up learning everything myself from the textbook and online.
I really liked his teaching. The notes were well done and clear(most of the time). He seemed to get an impish enjoyment out of students not understanding what was going on; it was rather amusing.

A good prof. You really have to listen for the things that he puts emphasis on, because they will be in the MT's or final. EXTREMELY helpful in office hours, is totally willing to help students get a good mark if you are willing to put in the work needed
He is confusing during the lectures.  Apparently, he thinks every student has a PH. D. in organic chemistry before this course

I can't seem to understand him during lectures.  He assumes you know so much information prior to taking this course.  Exams are fair and tend to be slightly on the easy side, which is good.  The textbook and tutorials really clarify the information he zooms through in lecture.

Nice prof but had a tendency of trying to fail his whole class. MT1 was ok, MT2 was hard, and final was impossible. He tends 2 repeat some exam Q's from before so make sure you have know da ans even after MTs coz THEY WILL APPEAR BACK ON THE FINAL... I guess every1 knows it's not a fun course~
I have trouble understanding him in class, but the tutorials really clarify important concepts.  The exams aren't too hard.

Too much pause between his words, which makes his speech so hard to understand+digest.Exams are slightly harder than expected.Our class average was about 50% for both midterms.Final kills!He likes to give out notes&important messages in the last minute.It's so hard to get enough prepration b4 class.
Something must have changed since his last ratings in 2003.  The poor averages on both midterms say somehings about his teaching ability.

She's a nice lady, but she just can't teach this course. A lot of technical issues in lecture had her pushing the two exams a week after the scheduled time. Because she doesn't know the curriculum, she expects you to know reactions not in 281. Thick accent and very hard to follow in lecture.

Dr. Bensari is one of those people who are very educated but suck at educating. She would almost always start the class early before many people were able to get to the lecture hall, she does not post the notes she makes in class, and references a lot of reactions that were not covered in CHEM 281. Do not expect a practice exam :')
study lots! Everything is based on exams and they can be difficult
sweet lady, extremely difficult exams

CHEM282 is notorious for being very hard and it doesn't help to have a prof like Dr. Bensari teaching it. Lectures are extremely hard to follow. The 60% final is exponentially harder than any of her practice problems or anything from the textbook. Expects you to know things not in the prerequisite courses. Often starts class early and ends late.

Don't look at the positive reviews. This guy will make you fail the class. He's very old school with his hand written notes. I couldn't even understand his hand writing. So, it's better to take this rigorous course with other prof. ANYONE BUT HIM! Trust me.

Dr. Pete is truly one of the best profs I have ever had at SFU. His lectures are really engaging and he explains the concepts really well and helps you to build a strong foundation of organic chemistry. Exams may be a bit challenging but he gives easy bonus questions and scales. I highly recommend taking Organic chem 2 with Dr. Pete.

Has a very old school way of teaching. His notes are mainly hand written (except for at the end of the course) and aren't posted before class, instead they're posted after so you can't annotate your notes as he talks. Speed runs that last topics of the course (rxn mechanisms), and from then on its all self taught and figuring it out yourself

Pete's old school yet kinda used to technology. He is a chill but not the best. His files are disorganized in my perspective and are overall just hard to read and figure out what concept you are learning. To be honest this course was mostly just self teaching. The course flies fast so know the topics and learn them outside of class if you can.

I wish Dr. Wilson would post slides ahead of time, as I found it quite difficult to get everything down during lectures. He posts his notes afterwards but the Canvas files are unorganized and hard to navigate. Exams were quite difficult and I spent hours upon hours of studying. The grade breakdown is rough and scale was only one letter grade.

if u dont attend lecture u will def not succeed. dr.wilson posts his notes after lecture and are hand written, so trying to understand it on ur own is difficult. practice sets were harder than the exam which is great for practice. exams were fair and is very clear in his questions, and even gives hints for several questions.

Dr. Pete is very nice and passionate about chemistry. His teaching style was not for me, he doesn't post his ancient hand written notes until after class. Make sure you attend every lecture because they aren't recorded either. Tests were very difficult and his problem sets didn't help me prepare much. I relied more on outside resources.

Dr. Pete is a sweet and caring professor. I had him for my lab also, and he would often let me stay overtime and patiently wait for us to finish our experiments if we were running late. The class itself is tough, but Dr. Pete has amazing notes and takes the time to explain. He also is very kind to help students in office hours. Hard work is key.

Not an approachable prof was often quite sassy.
Material was on exams that he said would not be covered yet he still covered it. Lectures were most often him rambling and his notes weren't that appealing.

i'd avoid taking this class with him. nice guy who seems to really enjoy the material, but it's not worth his mess of notes. handwritten notes and slides that don't explain much, lecture topics are all over the place making it really difficult to follow. you will have to teach yourself or pray you have a good TA.

He teaches very well but his course format is ARCHAIC!!! For the love of god he needs to combine his weekly lecture material into one, or just re-do his notes. Anyways, do the problem sets, go to office hours and you'll be okay! He's got a bit off sass but I think it's just the accent.

Pete's a kind person and probably the best Chem prof I've had at SFU. My biggest issues are that he delves too much into theory and how he crammed in a bunch of different reactions in the last ~2 weeks of class. My advice to do well is to actually go to tutorials and to watch lots of yt vids/do prac probs to solidify topics.
Good lecturer, fair tests with generous bonus marks. Class was scaled for sure. Would take again.

Pete is a great organic chemistry professor! He is very accessible outside of class, and his assignments are a huge help in terms of understanding the concepts. His exams are very fair, with many bonus points given out to help raise the average. Overall, he is passionate about what he teaches and you can tell that he cares deeply.

Probably my favorite ochem prof, you can tell he is very passionate about ochem and helping students to actually learn. Open door policy is nice, and he gives tons of bonus marks on exams which was really helpful. The second midterm was way harder than the first  (in chem 282 at least), so don't get comfortable too comfortable after the first one.

Pete is a great lecturer. He very clearly cares so much about his students and the class he teaches. He posts weekly problem sets that really help you prep for exams. The exam breakdown was a 40% midterm, and a 60% final, which was rather daunting but the exams being in person definitely did help as he was generous with allotted exam time.

Such a wholesome guy, but the course is super heavy. Unfortunately, his Canvas organization of the course is just bad. He tries to make chemistry a fun topic for us to learn, but it is just too much content. I do recommend taking ochem 2 with him to make your experience a bit more enjoyable, but otherwise, good luck studying.

really nice guy but his notes are all over the place and the course material is rather new from previous courses so you might need to teach yourself. His exams question are also not really taught on the notes but require some big brain energy to figure out so understanding all the concepts is pretty important. Nice guy but avoid if you can

Pete seems like a really nice guy, but his lectures dragged on for a bit and were a bit monotonous to the point where I would get bored and have a lecture into smaller parts to stay engaged. Scaling was generous and he seems like he cares that his students are actually learning though :)

Peter is a great guy but would sometimes get confused by his own lecture notes when explaining things, and would have to clarify it in the next lecture. His exams were fair but he asks a lot of questions, so don't focus too much on one thing because it covers everything, so know it all. But he wanted students to do well and was always funny!
The one man that can make organic chemistry interesting and understandable. Kindest man I've ever come across...
The one man that can make organic chemistry interesting and understandable. Kindest man I've ever come across.

The lectures were good and her way of teaching course was better than the professor teaching the same course. However, She uses much of critical analysis stuff to be examined on exams. Her exams are hard and lengthy but if you are preparing from textbook and her notes you can do well.

I like her notetaking approach - it's clear and concise. Use it as a guide in reading the book - because it's how it's supposed to be for a difficult course. She actually did us a favor in cutting down a lot of topics from the chapters  - but other students were just not aware coz they haven't opened the book. Do problem sets and practice problems

tests were absolutely on a different level than what was gone over in class. if you want to even pass you have to read the textbook and/or do extra problems. what she teaches will just be the absolute baseline of what she expects you to know. and she goes through lecture material very quickly.

Dr. Plettner isn't as bad as expected tbh. Her lectures are clear and thought-out (can get tiring, though) and she wants students to do well. If you ask for help, she will definitely make time for you. Go to office hours if you can. 
The course is very exam-heavy, the final was worth 55% and the midterm was worth 45%.

Exams are quite hard and the averages don't look good, although generally speaking she is a fair and okay professor. If she scales the class properly (which we deserve) then I would even give her 3.5. However, comparing her with 281's Robert something, she is definitely a lot better as she would post the class notes on canvas.

As long as you attend the lectures you'll be fine for the midterms. The main complaint I have is the fact that she doesn't release any answer keys for the tutorial worksheets/textbook problems, but aside from that she was a fair professor. She's very approachable and will take the time to clarify something for you if you don't understand.

Don't let the other reviews fool you. Midterm 1 was very fair, as she gave multiple review classes to help students prepare. She is approachable, polite and knowledgeable and seems to care about her students. In my opinion, she teaches a difficult course like OCHEM2 sufficiently.
Only thing is that there are no answer keys to review questions.
teach! be a little less rigid

Both the midterm and the final for this class were long, and so hard that I vomited afterward from sheer fear. But they get curved! Dr. Plettner is an extremely smart woman, and sometimes forgets we don't immediately understand the material like she does. Do the Mastering Chem assignments, they'll put the ton of notes into context.

Dr. Plettners lectures were alright but she never went into detail so it was difficult to understand. Textbook is an absolutely must. Cheat sheet didnt help on the final exam, she would ask very difficult questions. Doesnt respond to emails, however she is helpful in office hours. Overall would still avoid and wait for another prof.

Class was a waste of time. So much homework and the final exam was awful. The final was made so that a decent number of people couldn't finish, curves to the top mark so it's hard to get a good grade (probably got a B). Even with lots of effort you won't do great. Try Andrew Bennett instead, had him for Chem 281 and he was great (got an A-).

If you want to pass, DO NOT take this class with her. I got a B+ in the first ochem with Merbouh and thought i knew what i was doing. I  FAILED this ochem because I did not take the reviews seriously. Very difficult if you find multi-step synthesis  questions hard and are bad at problem solving type stuff. I will say she does give good feedback tho
just terrible, wait for someone else is good idea

Erika seemed quite overwhelmed most of the time and seemed to have a hard time answering questions from students which was a challenge because there aren't any answers to the problem sets or exams, and no textbook either so its easy to find yourself lost and struggling badly in her course

Erika puts a lot of unnecessary pressure on her students and can have a confrontational attitude towards some students even if they have a learning disability. she does not fulfil basic requirements of an instructor in my opinion.

Dr. Plettner isn't bad If you like O chem. I enjoyed taking O chem with her. If you go to office hours, she is very helpful. However, her notes can be a tad inconsistent, but I prefer written notes. Anything she writes down is fair game on an exam. Her final was extremely long, but surprisingly a lot easier than what people made it out to be.

CHEM 282 is a HARD course. With that being said, Dr. Plettner did a decent job with the difficulty of what she was required to teach. Personally, I found her notes consisted of too many diagrams without enough explanation. She explained things orally, but for the amount of notes she has the class take, it's hard to listen to everything she says.

Whoever walks into this class thinking it'll be a picnic, then kudos to you on your 4.0 GPA. But for the rest of us, this is a difficult course. Professor Plettner did a fantastic job with a difficult situation. Though she did seem colder than most profs, I found her to be quite nice and helpful once I gathered the courage to approach her.
Good explanations one on one. Terrible in lecture. One really needs to know concepts from 281 like a pro inorder to understand what she is saying for 282. Exams will leave you flabbergasted.

Really intense class & she made things more difficult than they needed to be. She would teach us easy things and test us on difficult things. She's nice and stuff but I wouldn't recommend her as a teacher at all. Take note everybody. Beware...

For an organic chemistry teacher, a good prof. Her midterm was alright, but her final was absolutely brutal. In lecture, VERY intensive notes. Will keep you constantly writing. However, her notes were fairly good. Very approachable and friendly person! Really liked how there were office hours everyday. Recommend you read the textbook!

Same as everyone else. Wanted to give her the benefit of the doubt, but she doesn't deserve it. Worst Prof I have ever encountered in 4 years post-secondary. Class is nothing but diagrams with no written explanations of anything. Uses an overhead, and explicitly states she does not want to be emailed.

I too thought it was biased as there rant many good ochem profs around.. and oh dear lord absolutely terrible person to approach especially if you are having troubles. So self centered and full of herself-_-. Didn't learn anything from her just constant taking down notes that had like maybe one or two words and the rest were drawings.

please, please heed these warnings as i also thought that these were biased opinions, but i was wrong!!!even though i passed the course, i will most likely retake the class with  dr merbough to actually learn ochem.

Wow, I can't believe all of these horrible ratings. I mean, she is not that bad. Maybe she is lacking on the people skills, but clearly these students don't study properly or get organic chemistry. I got an A+ with her and yes, her final was ridiculously hard, but she obviously scales. So if you study well and use the textbook, you'll be okay.

One of the worst I have ever had. Her lectures were terrible and I feel as though I was ripped off because I had a genuine interest in OChem before taking this course. I also feel like she did not teach what is required for my upper courses and I will be having to learn it on my own all over again for my next classes. AVOID.

Not a good professor at all. Knows her stuff but doesnt know how to teach. You spend most of your time writing down her notes and can barely pay attention. Need to study everything yourself by using textbook. TAs could have done better job at teaching. Midterm was easy. Final was super hard, and included stuff that wasn't taught but was in textbook

Everything up to the m/t was fine: fair m/t, decent notes, easy to follow. Everything after was terrible: no time to digest her lectures as she just kept writing down reactions, and the final was COMPLETELY beyond comprehension. Further, she will ALWAYS keep you in for i-clickers (once it went until 11:28). Honestly, try to avoid this professor.

Seriously the worst prof i've ever had.  Her notes are terrible as you cannot digest them after class; her final exam goes way beyond what is addressed in lecture; and her helpfulness is just pathetic.  When asked what pages from the text we should be reading, her answer was "Everything!".  Plus she always keeps you in to do the iclicker questions.
stay away from her

I always think that these comments are a bit biased. Perhaps only bad students complain...decided to risk it. BIG MISTAKE!!! During lectures, seemed like she didn't realize we were there & just talked to herself. She told us that final exam would be shorter since she only gave 38min for midterm. More than 90% of students still there after 3 hrs.

As a mature student returning to post sec ed, I am shocked at the caliber of this so called educator. She is a researcher and should not be teaching!!! Never been treated so disrespectfully by anyone let alone a prof. Horrible lectures, & when asked for clarification, she gets offended. If you value your gpa, DO NOT take from her...wait a term!!!

very slow and boring, is all over the place with notes and needs to liven the class up.talks to students as if in elementary school and uses tiny models for emphasis that only students in front can see.T.A's are giving mini lectures ahead of her because she is very unorganized.
exam questions are interconnected in which you are required to answer the previous question correctly in order to answer the next. Her attitude was horrible, even Kreis is much better~

i think she may have read these comments and made an improvement lol.i took chem 282 with her, her notes were good, she was clear, her exams were fair. i mean it had a certain level of difficulty..but its chem ..cmon.. She was helpful with students..and really wanted everyone to understand. and she let us have a cheat sheat!!!

Dim lights when asked to turn up the mic; ignore students' questions; changed exam questions (take home research, then write about in exam) on us.  Probably the worse professor I have had in this institution. Need to turn down ego a notch.

the mose useless professor ever...her notes are incoherent and makes no sense when you look back at them. Her assigned textbook readings are like 1 or 2 pages that won't even help you do her assignments and you gotta look it up yourself.

I will  not lie, she is dry, but if you are able to keep awake, she has really important things to say. OU MUST WRITE YOUR OWN NOTES, she won't write down all the important concepts, but she'll say them. Very pleasant to talk to, I'd love to take another course with her. CIAO!
Guest lectured for Dr. Kreis for a week. She explains concepts very clearly and points out common pitfalls. I was sad to see her go. I wish she was the prof for 282 instead of Kreis.

This professor is awful. Although he was fine in the first half , and his midterm was fair midway. After the midterm he completely switched. He was extremely rude and would make fun of students for asking questions. He blamed the students for the 30% average on the final exam rather than the difficulty of the exam.

The professor is all funny and enjoyable until you see the exam. We all wasted our time studying for nothing to be crushed by a difficult exam that de motivates us. He explains really well but ruins it by showing us the hard exams thats nothing like the tut,lectures, or even the review sessions he make.

Dr. Merbouh can really teach. Lectures are engaging and he gets to the point. He constantly made sure the class was following and would go over things even if we shouldve already known them. Gets upset if class doesnt participate but you can tell its cuz he cares. Exams are difficult but FAIR. He is a scary guy but also has a good sense of humour.

Bro thinks he's a standup comedian and wastes half the class time trying to humor us rather than teach us. We barely finished learning the midterm material (wednesday for a 40% midterm on friday) because of how poorly he manages his time. I wouldnt even be this upset if the jokes were actually funny but I cant help visibly roll my eyes during class

Midterm was fair. Due to COVID-19, final was moved online and the reduced time allotted made it hard to complete -- material was still fair. Dr. Merbouh relates the course material to real-life scenarios which made this course more interesting. Definitely one of the better organic chem profs. Attend lectures and study hard - you'll be fine.
The best prof I've had EVER! Made it super amazing and fun! Hes a fun guy and has funny jokes!

Dr. Merbouh is passionate about the subject and making sure his students understand the material. He enjoys joking around during lecture but his teaching style is sometimes hard to follow as he switches between powerpoint slides and handwritten notes often. Do not fall behind! It's best to review the problems he shows during lecture and tutorial.

Nabyl's lectures are highly entertaining, he tries his best to make hard concepts as easy as possible. Overall, he's a great prof, he demands respect from his students and expects you to put in the work. Put in the work, don't fall behind, and you'll do fine.

Dr. Merbouh is a passionate prof & conveys that to students excellently through use of relevant examples. He truly cares about his students' academic progress &wellbeing, is very supportive &goes the extra mile to ensure for instance that a final exam review session is held in spite of a pandemic. So dont miss out on the chance to take his class

He writes out some mechanisms by hand during lecture which is kind of helpful. Apart from that, he likes to ridicule students for asking questions and calls you out for not paying attention. While some might find it "caring", if you dont want an intense lecturer, merbouh is not for you.

Dr. Merbouh is an amazing, dedicated prof. He goes out of his way to drill in what you need to know in order to be successful. Chem 282 is not an easy class - its a lot of work, and it takes a lot of time and practice. But the amount of problems he does in class together, tutorial Qs and exam reviews, will prepare you thoroughly for his exams.

Dr. Merbouh is an amazing professor. I never zone out during his lectures. He is very passionate about organic chemistry and motivates students to work hard. I enjoy that he talks about applications of organic compounds in different subject areas (biochemistry, health science, etc.). Tutorial problems + office hours SUCCESS!

Professor Nabyl was one of the best chem professors I have ever had. The class itself is difficult, but that is mainly because of the material and not the teaching style. As long as you do the practice that the TAs and Nabyl assigns you, you should be sure to do well. Try to participate in class, and if you get a chance, go and see him for help

Nabyl is one of my favourite professors. He may come off as tough in the lectures, but in office hours he is so patient and very helpful. Student understanding is clearly a top priority for him, and he has been amazing through the transfer to online learning. His exams are fair, there are no surprises. Great prof.

Nabyl is one of those rare professors who actually cares about his students' success. He will make you feel dumb if you ask dumb questions, but he will always clarify any confusion you have. He wants you to succeed, and he actually puts effort into his lectures. His tests were pretty fair, but make sure you keep up with the work: it's still ochem.

Nabyl is a hardworking, amazing, hilarious prof. His lectures are easy to read and follow. Attend class and DO THE TUTURIALS and all extra questions and reviews he provides. Do not waste time on textbook. Focus on understanding his lectures. He will embarrass you in front of everyone, but it comes from a good place and it is to help you learn.

Merbouh genuinely cares about his students' success. He even gave us a pep talk to keep trying even if we don't think we can do it. His exams may be difficult but very straight forward and fair. This course requires students to put in their end of the effort. If you do all the tutorial and the practice problems he gives out then you're set.

Professor Merbouh is a great lecturer, he is very dedicated to helping his students learn and stops at nothing to make sure his class is succeeding. Also extremely understanding in the transition to online classes, and worked very hard to make sure we had resources available to guide is in our studying.

I'd honestly select more than one tag if it was possible. He's an amazing prof that's ready to help you anytime, anywhere, and he's also very dedicated. Yes, he roasts people, but that's his humurous side. He goes out of his way to answer your questions (after roasting you, of course) and is very knowledgeable in chemistry. He's an absolute gem.

Professor Merbouh really shows that he cares about his students and conducts review sessions before midterms and finals. He makes organic chemistry fun and his lectures are super engaging and interactive. I recommend him to all my friends because he's really good at explaining mechanisms and elaborates on what he expects us to know for exams.

Dr. Merbouh is one of the best chemistry professors I have ever had. He genuinely cares about his students and clarifies any confusion occurred during lectures. He is accessible during office hours. 100% would recommend him, especially for Ochem 2 which is a mechanism heavy course. So pleased that I could take a class with him.

He is very unhelpful and rude. While some might call this funny, it definitely is not when he gives you weird answers and makes you feel dumb for not knowing something. His tests are very pathetic and so are the averages. I had to put majority of my time into it despite being good at o-chem. I would avoid him and take it with Prof. Britton instead.

The TAs he chooses are extremely helpful. The midterm and final are similar to the tutorial questions and the practice exams he provides so make sure you work on those. Make sure you don't fall behind though because he goes slightly fast in lecture so you should know what you're doing. Lecture slides and in class notes are very helpful.

Nabyl is a great prof! He does his best to make sure his students understand the material and will hold many review lectures for our benefit. Final was similar to the practice questions he put up & there were no trick questions. He is also really funny and made lectures very enjoyable. He does supplemental in class notes to his slides so go

A real gem! His passion makes anyone fall in love with Organic Chemistry. He provides real life examples for all the concepts he teaches. He is really caring and selfless. He sacrifices from his own time to hold multiple review sessions and office hours to ensure everyone do good in his class. His exams are fair with no tricky questions.

Hands down the best prof I have ever had. I hope to take classes with him in the future and I will even if I do not require the class. He cares a lot about your learning. I highly recommend getting to know him as he likes to befriend his students. He believes in hard work and has been a great inspiration this semester.

love this guy, actually teaches and gets you to understand the material needed. nothing extra. he is very into chem and would be more than happy to help you understand. grade is fully dependent on 2 midterms worth 40% and 60% so work hard and practice a lot for them !!! text book will also help if you are willing to read

Great OChem Prof! His lectures are something to look forward to. The material is hard, so prepare to work. Pay close attention to in-class examples and do your tutorial problem sets, all this work will pay off on the exams. He's a tough grader, but scales the marks in the end.

Nabyl was an awesome prof, he put a lot of effort into teaching and actually cares about his students learning. Very big personality and being in his class was a lot of fun. Only 2 assessments for this course and the final (60%) was pretty hard. Content of his lecture and slides are all taken from the textbook, use the text to supplement his slides

Merbouh's the kind of prof you'd have a beer with-- after he wrecks your grades-- but with love. His midterm was VERY managable, but bring lube for the final because you will get... He genuinely cares about his students, but as a hard working prof, he expects quite a bit. Definitely not a class you want to slack in so buckle up if you're taking it!

Merbouh is a good prof, he's educated on the subject and tries his best to keep it interesting. The course itself is very unfair. The first midterm (40%) was fine but the final (worth 60%) was much more difficult than he said it was going to be. His slides don't fully reflect what he expects you to know and the final wasn't similar to tutorial Q's

He is a great hardworing guy and makes class fun, however his final was so much different than first miderm AND tutorials which was worth 60%... It was very difficult final specially for people who are not in chemistry.

Took 281 with him and he was great... the tutorials really helped with the course and it was straight forward. However, 282 was very different and made the final exam way more difficult than necessary when it was worth 60% of our grade . Told us an easy 100% if you study which was very misleading. His humor is also rude more than anything .

Hands down One of the BEST PROFS at SFU !! if you get a chance to take a course with him JUST DO IT! He is always available to answer any questions! He will find ways that work for you to understand the material! Be ready to stay on top of lectures and tutorial problem sets and then life becomes really really easy, nothing to write home about!

Merbouh is a top tier example of what it means to be an outstanding professor. His lecture notes are highly organized, and his explanations are thorough. He keeps the class entertained charismatic humour and his ability to make memorable connections on topics discussed in class. Above all he's the very definition of tough love as respect is earned.

Merbouh is a great professor. It's clear he has a strong understanding of the subject. He is great at explaining everything , but he is egotistic and wastes way too much class time telling stories, making jokes or picking on the students who ask for help. Tests are HARD. Midterm exam was difficult but fair, but the final was ridiculous.

This course is hard just because of the volume of material. Merbouh gives you tons of practice problems and review sessions, and is super accessible outside of class. He is hilarious and keeps lectures engaging. You will have to study on your own and put in work, but her really cares about his students. Tests are VERY fair/easy if you put in time
awesome class great proof, explains everything so well
The best prof I've come across in at SFU and i was lucky to have him for this class. Dont be intimidated by him, just show hard work and effort and he help you succeed.

Merbouh is a good prof!Very hurmourous and many girls love him! His exams are easy and he likes holding many review session before Final.Unbelievable that I got a C+ in this course!i got final of 58% but average is ard 70%,thought i would fail.Although he is easy to lose temper and make you afraid him, but he'll let you pass!

I failed this class with Bennett last term and retook it with Merbouh & got an A-! Best prof I've had at SFU, hands down. Finally a prof who can TEACH! It's impossible to fall asleep in his lectures & he's really intimidating but really funny too. Go to ALL lecs & do all tut Qs. If you respect him & work hard, he will reward you with a good mark.

Merbouh is by far the best organic chemistry prof at sfu. Not only did he make his lectures interesting but you actually wanted to attend. This class is a lot of work but Merbouh does a great job of telling you exactly whats on the test and hold review sessions for additional help. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!
He can be a hard prof, but he tells you what to study for. And if anyone says he's brutal that is because O Chem is not an easy course, follow the book and you'll do fine.

You must work extremely hard to succeed in his class however, he does reward your hard work.  Gets his message across very well, and the notes are informative especially if you fill in all of the extras.  Helped me out HUGE with doing well in O-Chem.  Thanks DR. Merbouh!
My favourite quote he says: If I can't outsmart you, I will outwork you. This man is an inspiration

Merbouh has an uncanny ability to keep me awake during his lectures, no matter how sleepy I may be. He is straight-forward, and crystal clear on what needs to be done for class, and expects you to put in a good effort. He keeps the class entertained, and loves to highlight organic reactions by calling them the "typical poster boy".

It takes a lot of dedication to schedule a nmr review session in the evening for students who are not even taking your class. Dr. Merbouh is one of the few science professors who knows how to teach. Perhaps he is annoyed with the students' general lack of understanding, yet he makes a sincere effort to help and THAT'S WHAT COUNTS. He's also hot!

I think he was a bit hard (only cause i have a hard time being awake at school no matter what class it is), but an extremly nice person and very down to earth. Plus he is really really cute ;-) So it made going to class all the worth while.

He is a good person overall. His strongest points are: He knows his stuff and does his best to explain it to his students. Weakness: He should be a teacher rather than just a lecturer. "Having a PHD puts you in a leadership postion but does not make you a leader",so I think that he should try to make his students comfortable around him, not scared.

I don't know why people seem to have a problem with him.  I find his lectures to be extremely clear and helpful (I understand several concepts a lot better because of his 'guest' lectures).  He wants you to really think about the chemistry rather than just sit there not taking anything in during the lecture, and it helps a lot.  Excellent prof.

This professor was one of the best chemistry professors I've seen by far!  His teaching ability is amazing.  He can take a very abstract idea and simplify it so that even a child can understand it.  Not only does he teach you properly, he also does an amazing part by not putting you to sleep.  Definitely take his class!

His lectures are pretty much him throwing reaction mechanisms at us without explaining anything. Furthermore, if you go to his office hours, he won't answer questions, he'll just tell you to go look at your text book and make you feel dumb.
best prof ever! makes chemistry actually intresting to learn.. i hear he doesnt have much core strength though!

He is a good prof but he is so disorganized, his exams are hard ( average was 40 ) I hope he wont make the final so hard. If he makes it as hard as second midterm, then I guess half the class will fail and end up taking this class in summer again. Overall he is an approachable person to answer your questions.  Do not scare to ask question, he is al

for the whiners -- organic chemistry is standard university subject of considerable difficulty... get over it; exams will be hard. merbouh is not trying to be an ass, he's trying to motivate you. moreover, only a fool would criticize an academic for their english ability... intelligent ppl come from non-north american countries as well... surprise!

At first he seemed to be a very scary prof, but after you get to know him he's an excellent teacher! If you approach him during his office hours or in lab, he will gladly help you with any question you have. Just make an effort on your part first before going to him. He's your professor, not your high school teacher, he's not going to spoon feed yo
He is one of the best prof i ever had. Because of him, I actually enjoy chemistry now.If you want to learn chemistry take it with Dr. Merbouh

I don't recommend anybody to take chemistry 282 with Dr. Merbouh. He is very hard. Everytime he teaches this course, he examines his students not only on the chem 282 materials, but also on ALL OF THE CHEM 281. His midterms are extremely hard and challenging. He does not provide any sample exams. On my first midterm, the class average was 40%.
